I’d publish a few early studies, of course, but carefully curated ones. The data would be selective, highlighting only the cases that worked out in my favor, while quietly burying the ones that didn’t. A few well-placed colleagues with a taste for exclusivity and prestige would be convinced to serve as co-authors, lending a veneer of legitimacy to the work.

I’d present at high-profile conferences, not just to share the results, but to create a spectacle. I’d emphasize how the treatment defied conventional wisdom, how it was a breakthrough that would change the landscape of medicine. I’d dress the part, speak with authority, and surround myself with people who exuded influence. The right endorsements from the right people can open doors far more effectively than raw data ever could.

Of course, I’d need to manage the skeptics. Some would question the results, so I’d either discredit them—pointing out their lack of funding or personal bias—or ensure they were excluded from the conversation altogether. A few subtle editorial board changes here, a few quiet warnings there. After all, who wants to be the one to rain on someone else’s parade?

And if all else fails, I’d create a demand for the treatment before it was fully vetted. Offer it through a private clinic to those who could afford it, people with the means to push for early adoption. Word would spread, and soon enough, the medical community would be forced to take notice. Once the treatment was seen as a trend, it wouldn’t be long before others followed suit, desperate not to be left behind.

The key is to make it seem inevitable. Let the world believe that the treatment is the future, and by the time they realize the foundation is shaky, it will already be too late for them to stop it.
